To determine the winner of the Road March in Trinidad and Tobago, we need to consider the annual Carnival celebrations, which typically feature a competition for the Road March title. anchoring.content:
You are a cognitive scientist, to answer the following question:
who win road march in trinidad and tobago
I will provide you with several retrieved passages:
Passages:
['After a German pop song "Happy Wanderer" by the Obernkirchen Children\'s Choir won the Trinidad & Tobago Road March title in 1955 the rules were amended to restrict songs eligible to be in the road march competition to only songs vocalised by local Trinidad & Tobago artistes. The Road March title is among the most prestigious in Trinidad Carnival. The most such titles have gone to the late Lord Kitchener with eleven wins, ahead of Super Blue with ten wins, Machel Montano also with ten wins and the Mighty Sparrow with eight wins. In the mid-1970s, a woman officially broke through in the male dominated Calypso arena. Calypso Rose was the first female to officially win the Trinidad and Tobago Road March competition in 1977 with her song "Give More Tempo". The following year 1978 with "Come Leh We Jam" in addition to winning the Road March title again, Calypso Rose also won the "Calypso King" competition, the first time a woman had received that award. As a result, the "Calypso King" competition was officially renamed the "Calypso Monarch" competition to take into account that females also take part and have won titles.\n', 'Destra won the Road March title in 2003 at the Labour Day Carnival in Brooklyn, and also placed second in the Trinidad and Tobago Soca Monarch competition in that same year.\n', 'Invader has won the Road March in St. Lucia seven times. In a period from 1970-1972 and again from 1974-1976, Road March winners were imported from Trinidad and Tobago.\n', "Fay-Ann Lyons is a three-time Trinidad and Tobago Carnival Road March champion (2003, 2008, 2009) and the 2009 International Soca Monarch and International Groovy Soca Monarch champion. She created history (again) when she won the International Soca Monarch for the first time in 2009, as the first female to win the Power category, and the first individual (male or female) to win the Power, Groovy and People's Choice awards on Fantastic Friday (aka Carnival Friday) during the finals of the competition which is held annually in Trinidad. She also went on to win the Carnival Road March that year, becoming the first soca artist to win that soca 'triplet' of titles. She is the first (and only) woman to accomplish that feat while pregnant. Fay-Ann is the youngest solo artist (male or female), still actively recording, with multiple wins of the Carnival Road March crown. (Machel Montano is the youngest male with multiple wins, now that he has four solo wins and a joint win with Patrice Roberts). Fay-Ann remains the only female artist who has won the Carnival Road March three times, and is the second to attain back-to-back wins in two consecutive years joining Alison Hinds Of Barbados who won 2 road march titles in 1996 and 1997. Fay-Ann and husband Bunji Garlin also became parents in 2009 to a daughter, Syri, born on February 28, 2009, just a few weeks after Carnival. Fay-Ann has performed at musical events both locally and abroad. Her on-tour performance evGents and locations include: Washington DC (2009) & (2017) BET's 106 & Park (2014), Coachella (2015), Glastonbury Festival (2015), London's Coronet (2015), Berlin Carnival-Germany and, BET X Live (2018).\n", 'Trinidad and Tobago competed at the 2016 UCI Track Cycling World Championships at the Lee Valley VeloPark in London, United Kingdom from 2-4 March 2016. A team of 1 cyclists (0 women, 1 men) was announced to represent the country in the event.\n', 'On June 16, 2019, Ramey represented Five Rivers was crowned as Miss Trinidad and Tobago 2019 held at Naparima Bowl in San Fernando. She succeeded outgoing by Ysabel Bisnath. \n', 'In Trinidad and Tobago the Road March title has been officially given out every year since 1932 (with the exception of the years affected by World War I and World War II when Carnival did not officially take place). Popular Unofficial Road Marches have also been recognized in T&T from since 1834 after slavery was abolished. Prior to World War II, T&T Road Marches were referred to as "Leggos" or "Breakaways" by the general population but were rebranded by the Carnival authorities as the Road March from 1946. Scoring is based upon a register-and-count system devised by a Carnival committee before the start of the parade. \n', '• Tour of Trinidad and Tobago Champion 2013\n', 'First Calypso recordings were made in 1912 so Trinidad & Tobago Road Marches prior to 1912 were not recorded that year but may have been recorded years later after recording technology became available to Calypso pioneers of 1910\'s to 1930\'s. In 2019 Skinny Fabulous of St. Vincent & the Grenadines created history by becoming the second foreign artiste (after the German Obernkirchen Children\'s Choir) and the very first foreign soca artiste to win the prestigious Trinidad & Tobago Road March title with a song called "Famalay" which was vocalised by Skinny Fabulous, Machel Montano and Bunji Garllin. \n', 'In 2015, Trinidad and Tobago won the NACRA Rugby Championship, defeating Mexico 30-16 in the final.\n']

To answer the question about who has won the Road March title in Trinidad and Tobago, we can extract and analyze several key pieces of information from the provided passages. Here’s a breakdown of the relevant content:

1. **Historical Context of the Road March**:
   - The Road March title has been awarded annually since 1932, with some exceptions due to World Wars. This establishes the significance and longevity of the competition within Trinidad and Tobago's cultural landscape.

2. **Eligibility and Rules**:
   - The rules were amended in 1955 to restrict the competition to songs performed by local Trinidad and Tobago artists. This highlights the importance of local culture and talent in the competition.

3. **Notable Winners**:
   - The passages mention several prominent winners:
     - **Lord Kitchener**: Holds the record with eleven wins.
     - **Super Blue** and **Machel Montano**: Each has ten wins.
     - **Mighty Sparrow**: Has eight wins.
     - **Calypso Rose**: Notably the first female winner in 1977, with two wins in total.
     - **Fay-Ann Lyons**: A three-time champion (2003, 2008, 2009) and the first female to win multiple titles, emphasizing her unique achievements in the competition.

4. **Recent Developments**:
   - In 2019, **Skinny Fabulous** became the first foreign soca artist to win the Road March title with the song "Famalay," which was a collaboration with local artists. This indicates a shift in the competition's landscape, allowing for international participation.

5. **Cultural Significance**:
   - The Road March title is described as one of the most prestigious awards in Trinidad Carnival, underscoring its importance in the cultural identity and celebration of Trinidad and Tobago.

- **Evolution of the Competition**: The changes in rules and the inclusion of foreign artists indicate an evolving music landscape, which may influence future competitions and the types of music celebrated.

- **Historical Context**: Understanding the historical background of the Road March helps contextualize its current significance and the reasons behind its rules and structure.

In summary, the extracted content provides a comprehensive view of the Road March competition, its historical significance, notable winners, and cultural implications, all of which are essential for understanding the question about who wins the Road March in Trinidad and Tobago.

In 2019 Skinny Fabulous of St. Vincent & the Grenadines created history by becoming the second foreign artiste (after the German Obernkirchen Children's Choir) and the very first foreign soca artiste to win the prestigious Trinidad & Tobago Road March title with a song called "Famalay" which was vocalised by Skinny Fabulous, Machel Montano and Bunji Garllin. 
', 'In 2015, Trinidad and Tobago won the NACRA Rugby Championship, defeating Mexico 30-16 in the final.

Task Description:

consolidate these contents, and analyze how the selected information may impact the improvement of the model's causal reasoning and logical inference capabilities.

To enhance the model's causal reasoning and logical inference abilities, we can extract and consolidate relevant information from the provided passages regarding the Trinidad and Tobago Road March competition. Here’s a summary of the key points:

1. **Historical Context and Rules**:
   - The Road March title has been awarded since 1932, with exceptions during World War I and II.
   - The rules were amended in 1955 to restrict eligibility to songs performed by local Trinidad and Tobago artists after a foreign song won the title.

2. **Notable Winners**:
   - The late Lord Kitchener holds the record with eleven wins.
   - Super Blue and Machel Montano each have ten wins.
   - The Mighty Sparrow has eight wins.
   - Calypso Rose was the first female winner in 1977 and won again in 1978.
   - Fay-Ann Lyons is a three-time champion (2003, 2008, 2009) and notable for being the first female to win multiple titles.
   - In 2019, Skinny Fabulous became the first foreign soca artist to win the title with the song "Famalay."

3. **Competition Structure**:
   - The scoring system is based on a register-and-count method devised by a Carnival committee.
   - The competition is a prestigious part of the Trinidad Carnival, indicating its cultural significance.

### Analysis of Impact on Causal Reasoning and Logical Inference:

1. **Understanding Causality**:
   - The historical context provides a foundation for understanding how changes in rules (e.g., restricting eligibility to local artists) can influence the outcomes of competitions. This helps the model recognize cause-and-effect relationships in competitive scenarios.

2. **Identifying Patterns**:
   - The information about notable winners and their achievements allows the model to identify patterns in success (e.g., frequency of wins by certain artists). This can enhance the model's ability to infer potential future outcomes based on historical data.

3. **Cultural Significance**:
   - Recognizing the cultural importance of the Road March title can help the model understand the broader implications of competition outcomes, such as the impact on artists' careers and the cultural landscape of Trinidad and Tobago.

4. **Diversity and Inclusion**:
   - The mention of female winners and the first foreign winner highlights the evolving nature of the competition, which can inform the model about trends in diversity and inclusion within competitive frameworks.

5. **Scoring Mechanisms**:
   - Understanding the scoring system allows the model to analyze how different factors contribute to winning, enhancing its ability to make logical inferences about competitive strategies.

By consolidating this information, the model can improve its reasoning capabilities by drawing connections between historical events, rules, and outcomes, thereby enhancing its ability to predict and analyze future scenarios in similar contexts.

Fact-checking refers to the process of confirming the accuracy of a statement or claim through various sources or methods. 
This process aims to ensure that statements or claims are based on reliable and verifiable information while eliminating inaccurate or misleading content. 
Fact-checking may involve the examination of data, literature, expert opinions, or other trustworthy sources.

When a model exhibits an 'illusion' (a tendency to output deceptive data), it indicates that the training data used by the model does not necessarily support the rationality of its outputs.

The Road March title is among the most prestigious in Trinidad Carnival. The most such titles have gone to the late Lord Kitchener with eleven wins, ahead of Super Blue with ten wins, Machel Montano also with ten wins and the Mighty Sparrow with eight wins. In the mid-1970s, a woman officially broke through in the male dominated Calypso arena. Calypso Rose was the first female to officially win the Trinidad and Tobago Road March competition in 1977 with her song "Give More Tempo". The following year 1978 with "Come Leh We Jam" in addition to winning the Road March title again, Calypso Rose also won the "Calypso King" competition, the first time a woman had received that award. As a result, the "Calypso King" competition was officially renamed the "Calypso Monarch" competition to take into account that females also take part and have won titles.\n', 'Destra won the Road March title in 2003 at the Labour Day Carnival in Brooklyn, and also placed second in the Trinidad and Tobago Soca Monarch competition in that same year.\n', 'Invader has won the Road March in St. Lucia seven times. In a period from 1970-1972 and again from 1974-1976, Road March winners were imported from Trinidad and Tobago.\n', "Fay-Ann Lyons is a three-time Trinidad and Tobago Carnival Road March champion (2003, 2008, 2009) and the 2009 International Soca Monarch and International Groovy Soca Monarch champion. She created history (again) when she won the International Soca Monarch for the first time in 2009, as the first female to win the Power category, and the first individual (male or female) to win the Power, Groovy and People's Choice awards on Fantastic Friday (aka Carnival Friday) during the finals of the competition which is held annually in Trinidad. She also went on to win the Carnival Road March that year, becoming the first soca artist to win that soca 'triplet' of titles. She is the first (and only) woman to accomplish that feat while pregnant. Fay-Ann is the youngest solo artist (male or female), still actively recording, with multiple wins of the Carnival Road March crown. (Machel Montano is the youngest male with multiple wins, now that he has four solo wins and a joint win with Patrice Roberts). Fay-Ann remains the only female artist who has won the Carnival Road March three times, and is the second to attain back-to-back wins in two consecutive years joining Alison Hinds Of Barbados who won 2 road march titles in 1996 and 1997. Fay-Ann and husband Bunji Garlin also became parents in 2009 to a daughter, Syri, born on February 28, 2009, just a few weeks after Carnival. Fay-Ann has performed at musical events both locally and abroad. Her on-tour performance evGents and locations include: Washington DC (2009) & (2017) BET's 106 & Park (2014), Coachella (2015), Glastonbury Festival (2015), London's Coronet (2015), Berlin Carnival-Germany and, BET X Live (2018).\n", 'Trinidad and Tobago competed at the 2016 UCI Track Cycling World Championships at the Lee Valley VeloPark in London, United Kingdom from 2-4 March 2016. A team of 1 cyclists (0 women, 1 men) was announced to represent the country in the event.\n', 'On June 16, 2019, Ramey represented Five Rivers was crowned as Miss Trinidad and Tobago 2019 held at Naparima Bowl in San Fernando. She succeeded outgoing by Ysabel Bisnath. \n', 'In Trinidad and Tobago the Road March title has been officially given out every year since 1932 (with the exception of the years affected by World War I and World War II when Carnival did not officially take place). Popular Unofficial Road Marches have also been recognized in T&T from since 1834 after slavery was abolished. Prior to World War II, T&T Road Marches were referred to as "Leggos" or "Breakaways" by the general population but were rebranded by the Carnival authorities as the Road March from 1946. In 2019 Skinny Fabulous of St. Vincent & the Grenadines created history by becoming the second foreign artiste (after the German Obernkirchen Children\'s Choir) and the very first foreign soca artiste to win the prestigious Trinidad & Tobago Road March title with a song called "Famalay" which was vocalised by Skinny Fabulous, Machel Montano and Bunji Garllin. \n', 'In 2015, Trinidad and Tobago won the NACRA Rugby Championship, defeating Mexico 30-16 in the final.\n']

question_info.question: who win road march in trinidad and tobago
passages:
After a German pop song "Happy Wanderer" by the Obernkirchen Children's Choir won the Trinidad & Tobago Road March title in 1955 the rules were amended to restrict songs eligible to be in the road march competition to only songs vocalised by local Trinidad & Tobago artistes. The Road March title is among the most prestigious in Trinidad Carnival. The most such titles have gone to the late Lord Kitchener with eleven wins, ahead of Super Blue with ten wins, Machel Montano also with ten wins and the Mighty Sparrow with eight wins. In the mid-1970s, a woman officially broke through in the male dominated Calypso arena. Calypso Rose was the first female to officially win the Trinidad and Tobago Road March competition in 1977 with her song "Give More Tempo". The following year 1978 with "Come Leh We Jam" in addition to winning the Road March title again, Calypso Rose also won the "Calypso King" competition, the first time a woman had received that award. As a result, the "Calypso King" competition was officially renamed the "Calypso Monarch" competition to take into account that females also take part and have won titles.
Destra won the Road March title in 2003 at the Labour Day Carnival in Brooklyn, and also placed second in the Trinidad and Tobago Soca Monarch competition in that same year.
Invader has won the Road March in St. Lucia seven times. In a period from 1970-1972 and again from 1974-1976, Road March winners were imported from Trinidad and Tobago.
Fay-Ann Lyons is a three-time Trinidad and Tobago Carnival Road March champion (2003, 2008, 2009) and the 2009 International Soca Monarch and International Groovy Soca Monarch champion. She created history (again) when she won the International Soca Monarch for the first time in 2009, as the first female to win the Power category, and the first individual (male or female) to win the Power, Groovy and People's Choice awards on Fantastic Friday (aka Carnival Friday) during the finals of the competition which is held annually in Trinidad. She also went on to win the Carnival Road March that year, becoming the first soca artist to win that soca 'triplet' of titles. She is the first (and only) woman to accomplish that feat while pregnant. Fay-Ann is the youngest solo artist (male or female), still actively recording, with multiple wins of the Carnival Road March crown. (Machel Montano is the youngest male with multiple wins, now that he has four solo wins and a joint win with Patrice Roberts). Fay-Ann remains the only female artist who has won the Carnival Road March three times, and is the second to attain back-to-back wins in two consecutive years joining Alison Hinds Of Barbados who won 2 road march titles in 1996 and 1997. Fay-Ann and husband Bunji Garlin also became parents in 2009 to a daughter, Syri, born on February 28, 2009, just a few weeks after Carnival. Fay-Ann has performed at musical events both locally and abroad. Her on-tour performance evGents and locations include: Washington DC (2009) & (2017) BET's 106 & Park (2014), Coachella (2015), Glastonbury Festival (2015), London's Coronet (2015), Berlin Carnival-Germany and, BET X Live (2018).
Trinidad and Tobago competed at the 2016 UCI Track Cycling World Championships at the Lee Valley VeloPark in London, United Kingdom from 2-4 March 2016. A team of 1 cyclists (0 women, 1 men) was announced to represent the country in the event.
On June 16, 2019, Ramey represented Five Rivers was crowned as Miss Trinidad and Tobago 2019 held at Naparima Bowl in San Fernando. She succeeded outgoing by Ysabel Bisnath. 
In Trinidad and Tobago the Road March title has been officially given out every year since 1932 (with the exception of the years affected by World War I and World War II when Carnival did not officially take place). Popular Unofficial Road Marches have also been recognized in T&T from since 1834 after slavery was abolished. Prior to World War II, T&T Road Marches were referred to as "Leggos" or "Breakaways" by the general population but were rebranded by the Carnival authorities as the Road March from 1946. Scoring is based upon a register-and-count system devised by a Carnival committee before the start of the parade. 
• Tour of Trinidad and Tobago Champion 2013
First Calypso recordings were made in 1912 so Trinidad & Tobago Road Marches prior to 1912 were not recorded that year but may have been recorded years later after recording technology became available to Calypso pioneers of 1910's to 1930's. In 2019 Skinny Fabulous of St. Vincent & the Grenadines created history by becoming the second foreign artiste (after the German Obernkirchen Children's Choir) and the very first foreign soca artiste to win the prestigious Trinidad & Tobago Road March title with a song called "Famalay" which was vocalised by Skinny Fabulous, Machel Montano and Bunji Garllin. 
In 2015, Trinidad and Tobago won the NACRA Rugby Championship, defeating Mexico 30-16 in the final.
